DrNo

They also want to reduce the amount of acetaminophen available in over-the-counter medicine.
 
 The reasoning is essentially that people are too stupid to realize taking 20 extra strength Tylenol in a day is bad.
 
 How ridiculous is this? How far is too far when it comes to the government deciding what we are and aren't allowed to do?
 
 This is one of the quoted arguments in this article:
 
 "The 1,000 milligram pill should never be at the patient's discretion. It should only be prescribed by a physician," Teperman said. "If you took an entire bottle of Tylenol Extra Strength, three days later you would be in a coma and needing a liver transplant."
 
 Are you kidding? If you take an entire bottle of Tylenol Extra Strength, you DESERVE to be in a coma needing a liver transplant.
 
 FDA Panel Urges Ban on Vicodin Percocet - MSN Health & Fitness - Medications

snakespit

This is by far one of the dumbest things I have ever read in my life. 
 
 The really frightening part of the story is that these people are in an advisory role with the FDA. Had to be a government operation. emoticon_rolleyes
 
 If people are too stupid to take 5 minutes and educate themselves about what they are taking, how to properly take it, the correct dosage, and the risks associated with taking it...then they deserve to die. Think of it as chlorine for the gene pool. 
 
 Is it simply a need to justify their rediculous job that these ###### would suggest something like this? How does it make any sense at all that you could make a 1gm tablet available by script only, yet you could still buy a full bottle of 500mg tablets? Every single member of that so called "advisory panel" should be fired and given frontal lobotomies to prevent them from coming up with any more "good ideas".

Too many Americans are addicted to pain killers because they can't afford medical care to treat the pain and these pain meds are cheaper.
Accipiter

I would like to see the Tylenol removed from drugs like Vicodin, Lortab, Percocet ect.
 
 Lots of people on pain meds are at risk of liver damage because they take too many on occasion (against their doctors recommendations of course).
 
 I think the reason they put Tylenol into Vicodin, Lortab and Percocet is to discourage abuse but people abuse them anyway.
snakespit

Too many Americans are addicted to pain killers because they can't afford medical care to treat the pain and these pain meds are cheaper.

 I would agree partly. But also, many doctors find it easier to throw pills at people than to take the time to search for the real source of the pain. Many of the people addicted to these pain killers don't need them, yet still have doctors signing off prescriptions every month for them. Isn't that what the whole fuss is about the Michael Jackson case right now? Addiction to narcotic pain killers is seen in every social and economic class in this country. Get the doctors to stop handing them out like candy to people who don't need them, and you solve a good portion of the problem.
snakespit

I would like to see the Tylenol removed from drugs like Vicodin, Lortab, Percocet ect.
 
 Lots of people on pain meds are at risk of liver damage because they take too many on occasion (against their doctors recommendations of course).
 
 I think the reason they put Tylenol into Vicodin, Lortab and Percocet is to discourage abuse but people abuse them anyway.

 
 If people are dumb enough to swallow a handful of pills against their doctors recommendations, then so be it...they deserve what they get. Why should we have to get rid of an effective pain reliever because some people fail to take the personal responsibility to educate themselves and follow simple instructions? 
 
 And the Tylenol does discourage some people from taking too many at one time, but think of the trade off of getting rid of it. You might save a few livers, but at the same time people now take 15 at a time and end up overdosed and dead on the floor.
Accipiter

If people are dumb enough to swallow a handful of pills against their doctors recommendations, then so be it...they deserve what they get.

 This is one of the quoted arguments in this article:

 Don't you get it? This is what you get when you elect an emotionally responsive bunch of leftists who will react to any situation by trying to legislate the fix for everyone. It is the nature of this administration and democratic majority to use every excuse possible in order to expand the scope and responsibilities of Government in order to expand their powers over us to create a larger nanny state. And they will increase taxes, by whatever name they call them in order to finance their massive oversight such as the lie that going green will save the planet as they ignore the fact that China and India, the two largest Industrial polluters wouldn't sign the newest agreements just agreed upon this past week. 
 
 Our trustworthy News doesn't want to tell us about that. Why be negative and tell the American people that the huge personal costs we will incur because of this new GREEN Legislation, wont matter one bit since it will be totally nullified by the massive tonnage of heavy metals and other pollutants which the non compliant industrial nations will continue to spew into the air.
antonia

To say something germane, in general, I would favor deregulation ITO over-the-counter *stuff* and things that should be over-the-counter but aren't, and things that should be legalized and regulated (and brought out of the shadows and taxed) that aren't.
 
 Informative warnings and education, but let people decide for themselves. I don't think we need a doctor's stamp of approval for so many things.
 
 So I would keep the law out of the present levels of acetaminophen.
 
 But I'm someone who also thinks emergency contraceptives should be available over-the-counter (as well as the Pill), along with a host of other (normally physician prescribed medicines that they sometimes make people jump through ridiculous hoops for, while allowing others easy access, depending on your health benefits or how much they pay their doctor per hour).
 
 They hold people hostage with this b******t and tie up otherwise needed medical services in waste.
 
 They should also legalize, regulate and tax marijuana. It would likely jumpstart the economy of California, for starters (since it's their no. one cash crop), and help a lot of cancer patients, too. 
 
 So a bottle of acetaminophen? I don't think people deserve comas, but it wouldn't be the first time someone was rushed to a hospital to get their stomach pumped, with or without a prescription.

snakespit

Yeah, ok I get it, your flexible on that to suit the occasion, how convenient for you! emoticon_rolleyes

 
 Flexible on what? You are the one who presumed to tell me how I drive. I never mentioned either way. Of course, you should understand that my personal driving habits have absolutely nothing to do with my point about personal responsibility. Personal responsibility is not just about driving the speed limit, or taking the correct dose of medication, it is about taking responsibility for all of your actions and being willing to be held accountable for the consequences that they lead to. 
 
 For a great lesson on the growing lack of personal responsibility in America, see Hurricaine Katrina.
